lines.content: Kiki is a task manager chatbot — add todos, deadlines, and events, and let Kiki keep track of them so you don't have to!
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/kiki.Kiki.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run kiki.Kiki.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

Claude was used to add comprehensive Javadoc comments to methods and classes that did not already have Javadoc comments.
Claude was also used to improve existing Javadoc comments to be more specific and follow the course standards.
Claude was used to refine the GUI by
1. Cropping profile pictures as a circle
2. Highlighting errors, text will be shown in red if an error is encountered
Claude was used to add functionality to the bye command such that the app closes after a bye command

Kiki is a **desktop chatbot for managing tasks** — todos, deadlines, and events. It is optimised for use via a Command Line Interface (CLI) while still having the benefits of a Graphical User Interface (GUI).
1. Ensure you have **Java 17** or above installed.
2. Download the latest `kiki.jar` from the releases page.
3. Copy the file to the folder you want to use as Kiki's home folder.
4. Open a terminal, `cd` into that folder, and run:
5. Type a command in the chat box and press **Enter** or click **Send**.
- Shows all tasks currently in your list, numbered from 1.
here are the tasks in your list:
- Adds a task with no date attached.
- Adds a task that must be done by a specific date and time.
- Dates must follow the format `D/M/YYYY HHmm`.
- Adds a task that spans a start and end date and time.
- Dates must follow the format `D/M/YYYY HHmm`.
- Marks the task at the given index as completed.
- Marks the task at the given index as not done.
- Removes the task at the given index from the list permanently.
- Searches for tasks whose descriptions contain the given keyword (case-insensitive).
here are the matching tasks in your list:
Postpones a deadline or event by updating its date to a new one.
- For a **deadline**, the due date is updated.
- For an **event**, the end date is updated.
- Dates must follow the format `D/M/YYYY HHmm`.
Kiki saves your tasks automatically after every command that changes the list. The data is stored in `data/kiki.txt` in the same folder as the jar file. There is no need to save manually.
| Add todo | `todo DESCRIPTION` | `todo read a book` |
| Add deadline | `deadline DESCRIPTION /by DATE` | `deadline submit report /by 5/6/2026 2359` |
| Add event | `event DESCRIPTION /from DATE /to DATE` | `event meeting /from 6/6/2026 1400 /to 6/6/2026 1600` |
* Represents a command to add a task to the task list in the Kiki chatbot.
/** The task to be added to the task list. */
* Constructs an AddCommand with the given task to be added.
* @param task The task to add to the task list.
* Executes this add command by appending the task to the task list,
* saving the updated list to storage, and returning a confirmation message.
* @param tasks The TaskList to add the task to.
* @param ui    The Ui instance used to format the response message.
* @return A confirmation message indicating the task was added and the current list size.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui) {
return ui.showMessage("okay, added: \n" + task + "\n you have " + tasks.size() + " tasks in the list currently");
* Represents a user command in the Kiki chatbot
* @param tasks The TaskList object to operate on
* @param ui The Ui Object to interact with the user
public abstract String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui);
* Returns true if the command should exit the program
* @return boolean representing if command is an exit command
* Represents a command to delete a task from the task list in the Kiki chatbot.
/** The zero-based index of the task to be removed. */
* Constructs a DeleteCommand targeting the task at the given zero-based index.
* @param task The zero-based index of the task to remove.
* Executes this delete command by removing the task at the stored index from the task list,
* saving the updated list to storage, and returning a confirmation message.
* If the index is out of bounds, an error message is returned instead.
* @param tasks The TaskList to remove the task from.
* @param ui    The Ui instance used to format the response message.
* @return A confirmation message with the removed task and new list size, or an error message.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui) {
return ui.showMessage("okay, removed: " + removedTask + "\n you have " + tasks.size() + " tasks in the list currently");
return ui.showError("that task number does not exist!");
* Represents a command to exit the Kiki chatbot.
* Executes this exit command by returning the goodbye message from the UI.
* @param tasks The TaskList (not used by this command).
* @param ui    The Ui instance used to retrieve the goodbye message.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui) {
* Represents a command to find tasks whose names contain a given keyword
/** The keyword to search for in task names. */
* Constructs a FindCommand with the given search keyword.
* @param word The keyword to search for in task names.
* Executes this find command by searching the task list for tasks whose names
* contain the stored keyword (case-insensitive) and returning a formatted list
* of matching tasks, or a message if no matches are found.
* @param tasks The TaskList to search through.
* @param ui    The Ui instance (not directly used; output is built via StringBuilder).
* @return A formatted string listing matching tasks, or a no-match message.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui) {
sb.append("here are the matching tasks in your list:\n");
* Represents a command to list all tasks currently in the task list
* Executes this list command by building and returning a numbered list
* of all tasks currently in the task list.
* @param tasks The TaskList whose tasks will be listed.
* @param ui    The Ui instance (not directly used; output is built via StringBuilder).
* @return A formatted string containing all tasks numbered from 1.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui) {
sb.append("here are the tasks in your list:\n");
* Represents a command to mark a task as done in the Kiki chatbot.
/** The zero-based index of the task to mark as done. */
* Constructs a MarkCommand targeting the task at the given zero-based index.
* @param index The zero-based index of the task to mark as done.
* Executes this mark command by setting the task at the stored index to done,
* saving the updated list to storage, and returning a confirmation message.
* If the index is out of bounds, an error message is returned instead.
* @param tasks The TaskList containing the task to mark.
* @param ui    The Ui instance used to format the response message.
* @return A confirmation message showing the marked task, or an error message.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui) {
return ui.showMessage("you're welcome, i've marked this task as done: \n" + task);
return ui.showError("that task number does not exist!");
* Represents a command to snooze a task by updating its date to a new date
* in the Kiki chatbot. Only applicable to tasks with a date field (i.e. Deadline or Event).
/** The zero-based index of the task to snooze. */
/** The new date string in the format {@code d/M/yyyy HHmm}. */
* Constructs a SnoozeCommand for the task at the given index with the given new date.
* @param taskIndex The zero-based index of the task to snooze.
* @param newDate   The new date string in the format {@code d/M/yyyy HHmm}.
* Executes this snooze command by updating the date of the task at the stored index.
* If the task does not support snoozing (e.g. a ToDo), an error message is returned.
* @param tasks The TaskList containing the task to snooze.
* @param ui    The Ui instance used to format the response message.
* @return A confirmation message showing the snoozed task, or an error message if snoozing is unsupported.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui) {
return ui.showMessage("okay, task has been snoozed: " + task);
return ui.showError("invalid date! date must be in format D/M/YYYY HHmm");
* Represents a command to mark a task as not done in the Kiki chatbot.
/** The zero-based index of the task to mark as not done. */
* Constructs an UnmarkCommand targeting the task at the given zero-based index.
* @param index The zero-based index of the task to mark as not done.
* Executes this unmark command by setting the task at the stored index to not done,
* saving the updated list to storage, and returning a confirmation message.
* If the index is out of bounds, an error message is returned instead.
* @param tasks The TaskList containing the task to unmark.
* @param ui    The Ui instance used to format the response message.
* @return A confirmation message showing the unmarked task, or an error message.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui) {
return ui.showMessage("you're welcome, i've marked this task as not done: \n" + task);
return ui.showError("that task number does not exist!");
* Represents a single dialog box in the Kiki chatbot GUI, consisting of a small
* circular profile picture and a styled text bubble. User messages are right-aligned
* with a dark bubble; Kiki's replies are left-aligned with a light bubble.
* Error responses from Kiki are rendered in a distinct red-tinted style.
/** The label displaying the dialog text as a styled bubble. */
/** The circular profile picture of the speaker. */
/** Bubble style for normal Kiki replies. */
/** Bubble style for Kiki error replies. */
* Constructs a DialogBox with the given text, profile image, and bubble style.
* The profile picture is clipped to a circle for a polished avatar appearance.
* @param text        The text content to display in the bubble.
* @param img         The profile image to display as a circular avatar.
* @param labelStyle  The CSS style string to apply to the text bubble.
private DialogBox(String text, Image img, String labelStyle) {
// Clip the avatar to a circle
* Flips the layout to left-aligned, placing the avatar on the left for Kiki's messages.
* Creates and returns a right-aligned DialogBox for a user message.
* @param text The text content of the user's message.
* @return A DialogBox styled and aligned as a user message.
public static DialogBox getUserDialog(String text, Image img) {
* Creates and returns a left-aligned DialogBox for a normal Kiki reply.
* @param text The text content of Kiki's reply.
* @return A DialogBox styled and aligned as a normal Kiki reply.
public static DialogBox getKikiDialog(String text, Image img) {
var db = new DialogBox(text, img, KIKI_BUBBLE_STYLE);
* Creates and returns a left-aligned DialogBox styled as a Kiki error reply.
* @param text The error text content to display.
* @return A DialogBox styled and aligned as a Kiki error reply.
public static DialogBox getKikiErrorDialog(String text, Image img) {
var db = new DialogBox(text, img, ERROR_BUBBLE_STYLE);
* Represents an instance of the task manager bot, kiki
* Processes user input and returns the corresponding response from Kiki

* Returns welcome message shown when user first enters the chatbot
* Returns goodbye message shown when user gives an Exit Command
* Serves as the entry point for the Kiki chatbot application.
* This class is necessary as a workaround for JavaFX's requirement that the
* main class does not extend {@link Application} when launching from a JAR.
* @param args Command-line arguments passed to the application.
* Serves as the JavaFX entry point for the Kiki chatbot application.
* Loads the main window layout from FXML and sets up the primary stage.
/** The Kiki chatbot instance shared with the main window controller. */
private final Kiki kiki = new Kiki();
* Starts the JavaFX application by loading the main window layout and displaying the stage.
* @param stage The primary stage provided by the JavaFX runtime.
* Acts as the JavaFX controller for the Kiki chatbot's main application window.
* Manages the dialog container, user input field, and send button,
* and connects the UI to the {@link Kiki} backend.
/** The error prefix used by {@link Ui#showError(String)} to identify error responses. */
/** The scroll pane that contains the dialog container. */

/** The text field where the user types their input. */
/** The button the user clicks to send their message. */

/** The profile image representing the user in the dialog. */
/** The profile image representing Kiki in the dialog. */
* Initialises the main window after all FXML elements have been loaded.
* Binds the scroll pane's vertical value and the dialog container's width
* so content resizes correctly when the window is resized.
* Injects the Kiki chatbot instance into the controller and displays the welcome message.
* @param kiki The Kiki instance to use for processing user input.
* Handles the user's input when the send button is clicked or Enter is pressed.
* Detects whether Kiki's response is an error and renders it in a distinct style.
* Clears the input field after processing.
assert userInput.getText().isEmpty() : "User input should be cleared after handling";
* Responsible for parsing all user input for the Kiki chatbot
* Parses a user input string into a Command
* @param input The raw input string from the user
* @return A Command corresponding to the user input
* @throws IllegalArgumentException If the input does not correspond to a command
public static Command parse(String input) throws IllegalArgumentException {
assert words.length >= 1 : "Parsed command should have at least one command word";
throw new IllegalArgumentException("todo description cannot be empty");

return new AddCommand(new Event(eventDate[0].trim(), eventDate[1].trim(), eventDate[2].trim()));
throw new IllegalArgumentException("provide a valid task number to delete!");

* Handles loading and saving of task data for the Kiki chatbot.
* Tasks are persisted to a plain-text file using a pipe-delimited format.
/** The directory in which the data file is stored. */
/** The path to the data file. */
* Loads tasks from the data file and returns them as an ArrayList.
* If the data file does not exist, it is created along with its parent directory.
* Lines that cannot be parsed are silently skipped.
* @return An ArrayList of tasks loaded from the data file, or an empty list if none exist.
assert Files.exists(path) : "Data file should be created";
System.out.println(" failed to load saved tasks");
* Parses a single line from the data file and returns the corresponding Task.
* @param line A pipe-delimited string representing a saved task.
* @return The Task decoded from the given line.
* @throws IllegalArgumentException If the line does not correspond to a valid task type.
assert parts.length >= 3 : "Saved task in data file must have at least 3 parts";
* Saves the current list of tasks to the data file, overwriting any existing content.
* Each task is written on its own line using its {@link Task#toFileString()} representation.
* @param tasks An ArrayList of tasks to be saved. No task in the list may be {@code null}.
assert task != null : "Task to be saved should not be null";

* Constructs a Tasklist with the given tasks
assert task != null: "Task to be added cannot be null";

assert !keyword.isEmpty(): "Search keyword should not be empty";
